awd_titl_txt: NRI: INT: COLLAB: Program Verification and Synthesis for Collaborative Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing applications for robots currently requires advanced knowledge and skills in both robotics and software engineering. As a result, development of robot applications is currently only accessible to a very small segment of the population, excluding those who might have the deepest insight about potential application domains for robots (e.g., experts in logistics, manufacturing, marketing), those who might be better suited to design robot behaviors for human interaction (e.g., designers, artists, psychologists), and those who might be using and repurposing robots day-to-day (e.g., end-users, supervisors, maintenance personnel). This project aims to design and implement a suite of tools and methods, powered by developments in the field of programming languages, to enable the programming of interactive robots with minimal prior experience. These tools and methods will assist all stages of the programming process, including ideation of what the robot behavior should be, coding of the program, its testing on the robot to guarantee certain properties, and adapting the program for deployments in different contexts. The research will make robot programming accessible to the broader public and "democratize" it by substantially lowering barriers to engagement in technology development. Through collaborations with domain experts, the principles, methods, and tools created by the project will be applied to real-world robotics applications, transferring the scientific contributions of the project to robotics organizations. Through an integrated education program, computer science training and curriculum will be enhanced across three institutions by introducing new courses and course modules on robotics software development. To facilitate public understanding of and engagement with science and technology, a robot programming environment for elementary- and middle-school-aged children will be developed along with a structured curriculum for its use in an outreach summer program, and these will be widely disseminated as open-source materials.

The key innovation of the project is the development of novel paradigms for programming that use state-of-the-art program analysis and synthesis methods to support a wide range of programming tasks across the development cycle for robotics applications. Specifically, the project will support each stage of the cycle in three research thrusts with the following objectives: (1) facilitating the capture of user intent by translating designer and end-user intent captured through acting and dialogue into robot programs; (2) supporting iterative development and testing by facilitating the development, refinement, analysis, and synthesis of robust, reliable, and effective robot programs; (3) optimizing deployment by enabling the adaptation of existing robot programs into new environments, scenarios of use, and social contexts. The outcomes of these research thrusts will be integrated into a suite of robot programming tools within the ROS framework and deployed in real-world robot programming tasks in collaboration with industrial partners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Developing applications for robots requires advanced knowledge and skills in both robotics and software engineering. As a result, development of robot applications is currently only accessible to a very small segment of the population, excluding those who might have the deepest insight about potential application domains for robots, those who might be better suited to design robot behaviors for human interaction, and those who might be using and repurposing robots day-to-day. This project aims to design and implement a suite of tools and methods, powered by developments in the field of programming languages, to enable the programming of interactive robots with minimal prior experience. These tools and methods assist all stages of the programming process, including ideation of what the robot behavior should be, coding of the program, its testing on the robot to guarantee certain properties, and adapting the program for deployments in different contexts. This research takes important steps toward democratizing robot programming by substantially lowering barriers to engagement in technology development. 


The project made several key contributions to the field of robotics and human-robot interaction. It advanced the application of techniques for program verification and synthesis to robot programming. Enabled by those technical capabilities, we invented new interfaces for robot programming, including a tabletop programming environment using tangible figurines to allow demonstrations of desired robot behavior and a handheld tablet interface for sketching interactions in situ. We also developed new algorithms for social robots to automatically repair their programs based on implicit signals received from users during previous runs, or to automatically improve programs by adding non-verbal backchannel behaviors or adapting interactive robot programs to influence human perception. We also built new programming tools and community resources for an open-hardware and open-software social robot platform, FLEXI, which was used in over ten human-robot interaction research projects (with peer-reviewed publications) and outreach. The robot and programming tools are now being used in projects by other researchers at UW Tacoma, UCSD, and University of Michigan. Besides applications in social robotics, we also worked on developing tools for the physically assistive robot Stretch. We developed AccessTeleopKit for operating the robot via a browser-based interface, which is accessible to users with mobility limitations by allowing thorough customization of the interface. 


Over the last three summers, we were part of a team who deployed a Stretch robot in the home of a quadriplegic user for multiple weeks with iteratively improved versions of the AccessTeleopKit. Using our interface, the  user was able to perform many tasks of daily living from feeding himself and scratching an itch, to contributing to household chores and participating in social activities, such as playing games with his grandchild. Upon the user’s request, we also developed tools for programming simple robot actions via teleoperation and demonstrated its utility in the last deployment. The deployments also demonstrated the utility of customization, even for a single user, for creating different interfaces for different tasks. We ran an additional lab study involving participants with varying motor limitations, to demonstrate the feasibility and utility of end-user customization of teleoperation interfaces.


Educational activities in the project were centered around increasing access to undergraduate research opportunities. The PI developed a new seminar for undergraduates who are completely new to research to demystify it and give them basic skills, such as finding and reading research papers or asking good questions, before starting their first research project. The PI also continued to expose undergraduates in project-based robotics classes to the research conducted in this project.


In the advent of large-language model based code generation, this project took important steps towards understanding user needs, designing new interfaces, and developing tools that have the potential to change the way that most future robots are programmed.


Last Modified: 02/28/2024
Modified by: Maya Cakmak

Images (1 of )

    Maya Cakmak
    Henry using AccessTeleopKit
  • The toolkit developed in this project to create custom user interfaces for tele-operating robots.
    Vinitha Ranganeni
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Maya Cakmak
    AccessTeleopKit
